The Hackathon Kickoff!
Participating in my first-ever hackathon was a wild ride. As someone new to the hackathon scene, I didn‚Äôt really know what to expect. But with some determination, teamwork, and a little bit of luck, my team and I managed not just to participate‚Äîbut actually win!
The Journey BeginsIt was around 6 PM when I got a message saying it was going to snow that night. I quickly packed up my hoodie, grabbed my favorite keyboard, and headed out with my friend. Just like me, my teammates hadn’t done a hackathon before either, and none of us came from a computer science background, so we were already at a bit of a disadvantage.
When I got into the car, my friend casually mentioned, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just have a good time.‚Äù I couldn‚Äôt help but respond, ‚ÄúWell, if I‚Äôm doing this, I‚Äôm aiming to win.‚Äù It was one of those moments where you say something without fully knowing how it will turn out. He just laughed, not taking it too seriously.
Forming the TeamWhen the hackathon kicked off, while the other teams were diving into their projects, we were still trying to figure out what to build. But we had one advantage: we were all grad students. I had some app development experience, so I suggested we use Flutter. The first few hours were spent watching tutorials just to get it installed. My friend and I also procrastinated a bit‚Äîwe still had homework to do‚Äîso it wasn‚Äôt an easy start. It‚Äôs funny looking back now, but there was definitely some tension in the air.
Building the Project: Echoes of EqualityWith my background in app development, I took charge of setting up the architecture and showing everyone what was possible with Flutter. As we started implementing features, we all began to feel a bit more confident.
The Night StrugglesAs the night went on, we hit a snag. We needed to use Firebase, which is usually a breeze for me, but that night, it just wasn‚Äôt working. I wasted hours on it and couldn‚Äôt get it to work. Just when I was about to take a nap out of frustration, my friend managed to pull it off. It was a huge relief. But then, of course, we got greedy and decided to add more and more features.
The Final PushI could go on and on about the rest of the hackathon, but the bottom line is, we weren‚Äôt sure how it would turn out until the very end. But when we presented our app, everyone loved it. They were so impressed, they said they wanted to use it in their daily lives right away. In the end, we won both the Beginner Category and the LGBTQIA+ Category.
ReflectionsIt‚Äôs a bit of a drag that we couldn‚Äôt take the app any further, but we received a lot of appreciation from all over the CS department, including the Head of the Department. The organizer even mentioned us in a LinkedIn post! You can check it out here.
If you‚Äôre curious to learn more about “Echoes of Equality,” you can check out the project on DevPost.
GalleryHere’s a collection of images that capture the spirit of the hackathon:
I hope this gives you a good sense of what it‚Äôs like to participate in a hackathon. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned coder or a newbie like I was, there‚Äôs something incredibly rewarding about pushing your limits and seeing what you can achieve.
title: My First Ever Hackathon Experience: Spoiler Alert - I Won!

content: Moving from Golden Rock in India to Golden, Colorado, has been a journey filled with cultural contrasts...Tap Water: The First Scary SipBack home in India, tap water is something you wouldn't dream of drinking without boiling or filtering first. But here in the US, everyone drinks straight from the tap! At first, I hesitated and stared at the glass, wondering if this was a good idea. But soon, I got used to it, and now, I love the convenience (though I still miss our boiled water).The Mysterious Toilet Seat CoverIn India, we flush and typically use a handheld hose (or bidet) to clean up‚Äîit's quick and thorough. But here in the US, I was introduced to a completely different approach: toilet paper, wipes, and the mysterious toilet seat covers. At first, it was a bit of a puzzle to figure out how to use these covers, but once you get the hang of it, it‚Äôs a pretty neat way to keep things clean. If you‚Äôre as confused as I was, check out this video on how to set one up:Also, public restrooms are super clean here, which I absolutely love. It's something I strive to maintain wherever I go.Tipping and Taxes: Surprise at the RegisterOne of the biggest shocks was at the cash register‚Äîwhy is the price higher than what‚Äôs on the tag? Welcome to the world of taxes that aren‚Äôt included in the price, and don‚Äôt forget to tip! It took a while to get used to tipping 15-20% on everything, but it‚Äôs just part of the culture here.Honking: It‚Äôs Not What You ThinkIn India, honking is like saying, "Hey, I'm here!" In the US, honking is more like, "What are you doing?!" It‚Äôs less about signaling and more about expressing displeasure, which I quickly learned to avoid.The Gym: Pounds and Public NudityAs someone who hits the gym regularly, I quickly realized that everything here is in pounds (lbs), not kilograms. To make life easier, I created an app that helps with these conversions‚Äîcheck it out if you‚Äôre in the same boat:Converter4MeOh, and don't be surprised if people walk around naked in the locker rooms. It's totally normal here. Just smile and carry on.Drinking: Cheers!Drinking is a pretty normal and socially accepted activity here. Whether it‚Äôs a casual drink after work or a weekend hangout, alcohol is a common sight.Holding Doors: The Unexpected CourtesyOne of the most charming aspects of American culture is the way people hold doors open for others. It‚Äôs such a small gesture, but it really makes your day. I‚Äôve started doing it myself, and it‚Äôs a habit I‚Äôm happy to pick up.Navigating these cultural differences has been both amusing and enlightening. Moving to a new country comes with its challenges, but it‚Äôs these little quirks that make the journey worthwhile. If you‚Äôre an international student or just curious about these cultural contrasts, I hope you enjoyed this peek into my experience!
title: The Culture Shock: From Golden Rock, India to Golden, CO, US
